thread.title: NL Wild Card: Pirates in-game analysis
thread.title_full: NL Wild Card: Pirates in-game analysis

author: ehall@timesonline.com(Eric Hall)
title: NL Wild Card: Pirates in-game analysis
text:
NL Wild Card: Pirates in-game analysis By Bill Allmann Times Sports Correspondent Timesonline.com | 0 comments 
Bill Allmann gives you inning-by inning analysis of the NL Wild Card against the Cubs Wednesday. 
After four innings, Chicago 3, Pittsburgh 0 
Cole's pitch count is up to 65 so it may not be a long night for the big righthander but it's looking more like the bullpen may not need to worry about Friday. The Pirates went down in order in the bottom of the 4th and Arrieta has now retired 11 in a row. 
It's hard to believe that a season with 98 wins may not be remembered as a success but there are some that will. 
After three innings, Chicago 3, Pittsburgh 0 
The Hurdle gambit to start Sean Rodriguez at first base for defensive purposes ended in the bottom of the third when Pedro Alvarez pinch hit for Rodriguez and then stayed in to play first base. Arrieta, though, made the defense/offense strategy meaningless though as, pitching with a three-run lead, he struck out the side. 
Interestingly, the Pittsburgh Police boat was just patrolling under the Clemente Bridge. It appeared that it was routine and not because of any jumpers. Yet 
After two and a half innings: Chicago 3, Pittsburgh 0 
Joe Maddon gambled and put Kyle Schwarber in right field despite limited experience there because Maddon wanted his offense. After an RBI single in the first, Schwarber added a two-run homer deep to right field in the third and Maddon looks like a genius. 
After two innings, Chicago 1, Pittsburgh 0 
Both pitchers settled down in the second and neither team recorded a hit. 
After one inning: Chicago 1, Pittsburgh 0 
Don Larsen fans can relax - there will be no perfect game tonight. Andrew McCutchen singles in the Pirates first but gets no further. 
After one half inning: Chicago 1, Pittsburgh 0 
Finally, the hoopla ended, and the baseball started. It didn't start well for the Pirates, though. Dexter Fowler singled to center field, stole second on the next pitch, and scored on a single by Kyle Schwarber - one of the players Joe Maddon started for his offense. After a double play, Anthony Rizzo reached on an error by Neil Walker - despite the Pirates stressing defense in this lineup. Cole struck out Tommy La Stella looking to end the inning. 
In the pregame, Maddon stressed the importance of getting an early lead with his offensive lineup, and it happened. Hurdle stressed defense and didn't get it... but there are 8 1/2 innings yet to play. 
Andrew McCutchen's mom did a great job on the national anthem, and the crowd erupted when Jung Ho Kang was wheeled onto the field in a wheelchair. 
Bob Walk just threw out the first pitch, so it's only minutes until the first pitch. Now, there's a video about past Pirates successes, narrated by Michael Keaton - the other Batman with Pittsburgh connections. 
There have only been four wild card games in the history of the National League – and this will be the third to be played in Pittsburgh. The game features a classic matchup of offense versus defense. Pirates manager Clint Hurdle has structured his lineup to maximize defensive efficiency – starting Sean Rodriguez over Pedro Alvarez or Aramis Ramirez at first base. Cubs manager Joe Maddon has structured his lineup to maximize its offensive potential – starting Kris Bryant in left field and Kyle Schwarber in right field, not the positions they played in the regular season. 
All the lineup tinkering has been magnified because there seems to be little room for error in the pitching matchup. The Cubs are starting Jake Arrieta, who has turned in the most dominating second half in history and the Pirates started Gerrit Cole, who won 19 games and has been the ace of the Pirates staff all year. 
After each team played 162 games hoping to avoid playing in a sudden-death matchup, it's time to play it anyway. They're introducing the entire rosters now so action should start soon. 
Let's follow the action with updates every inning - or half inning if it's worth it.
